docs.lead_paragraph: SO whatever happened to medical savings accounts? Please pick your eyelids off the floor. This is actually an important question. These accounts, which allow some income to be put aside each year, untaxed, to pay for health care, were presented just a few years ago as a panacea for the Big Health Insurance Crisis. They have not exactly caught fire, and the reasons say much.

headline.main: A Spending Account in Need of a Cure

docs.abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer Money & Medicine column on stagnation of medical savings accounts, created by Congress in 1997; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE only president whose wild mood swings prompted his own secretary of defense to issue orders designed to block him if he called out the Marines for protection against impeachment is also the only president known to have been treated by a psychotherapist. That president was Richard M. Nixon, and both of those experiences are chronicled in ''The Arrogance of Power: The Secret World of Richard Nixon,'' by Anthony Summers (Viking). And while other accounts in his book, including episodes of wife-beating and pill-popping, are angrily contradicted by Mr. Nixon's defenders, the revelations about the secret order and the president's psychiatric treatment have not been widely disputed.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; Most Presidents Had a Counselor. One Had a Shrink.

docs.abstract: Revelations about Pres Nixon's psychiatric treatment, in Anthony Summers' book, The Arrogance of Power: The Secret World of Richard Nixon, raise important questions; overwhelming majority of politicians still hide their mental difficulties; many will speak openly about family or close friends who struggle with mental illness, but not about themselves; several politicians who did publicly acknowledge mental illness and treatment have been re-elected to Congress, but there is general agreement that candidate for president would face tougher barrier; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Health; Washington; Books; Week in Review

docs.lead_paragraph: In Florida, where retirees have been flocking since the 1920's and where 25 percent of the state's population is expected to be over 65 by the year 2010, there are growing feelings of strain and exhaustion among the managers, the nurses and nurses' aides who care for the old and frail. The word most often heard in conversations with elder-care professionals these days is ''crisis.'' With a population calculated to be aging at a rate 20 years ahead of the nation as a whole, the Sunshine State has become a harbinger for a nation growing old and facing problems with long-term care for the aged. As the average life span lengthens, people seem healthier in old age than ever before. The question is how to serve those who become infirm or ill. In Florida and in the nation, most of that burden falls, as it always has, on families, usually on a woman caring for an older one. In Florida, a study four years ago found that almost 80 percent of the frail elderly were cared for at home. African-American and Hispanic families are more likely to care for their own, says Larry Polivka, director of the Center on Aging at the University of South Florida, whereas more whites seek professional help. But there is no way to know what quality of care the people at home actually get, or what sacrifices their care-givers have to make to give it.

headline.main: Editorial Observer; The Crisis in Providing Care for the Elderly Ill

docs.abstract: Dudley Clendinen, in Editorial Observer column, holds that in Florida, where 25 percent of state's population is expected to be over 65 by year 2010, there is 'crisis' in providing long-term care for aged (M)c

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman returned to the warm embrace of his hometown today, where he criticized Gov. George W. Bush, telling a group of older residents that Mr. Bush would do nothing to strengthen Medicare. Mr. Lieberman, joined by family members, was welcomed like a returning son to the Bella Vista retirement home here as he made his first swing through Connecticut since accepting the nomination as the Democratic vice-presidential candidate.

headline.main: Lieberman Returns Home and Attacks Bush's Drug Plan

docs.abstract: Sen Joseph I Lieberman campaigns in New Haven, Conn; tells residents of retirement center that Gov George W Bush would do nothing to strengthen Medicare; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today vetoed a Republican-sponsored bill to repeal the federal estate tax and stepped up the election-year sparring over tax cuts and how best to spend the budget surplus. In remarks in the East Room of the White House, Mr. Clinton said the bill ''fails the test of fairness and fiscal responsibility'' because it is costly and, according to administration figures, benefits only the wealthiest 2 percent of the population.

headline.main: PRESIDENT VETOES EFFORT TO REPEAL TAXES ON ESTATES

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton vetoes Republican bill to repeal federal estate tax as failing 'test of fairness and fiscal responsibility' because it is costly and benefits only wealthiest two percent of population; Clinton accuses Republicans of endangering economy with tax cut plans that would leave little money for Medicare, prescription drug benefits, education and other programs, and take nation back to 'bad old days' of deficits; photo with South Dakota farmer John Sumption; Speaker Dennis Hastert plans override attempt, although neither side rules out compromise (M)
